bibl.title: Notes about Camp Lee, by [Henry Rose Carter, 1917] [Enclosed in C0128011]

div1.p: This documents surveys breeding areas at Camp Lee.

div1.head: Notes about Camp Lee, by [Henry Rose Carter, 1917] [Enclosed in C0128011]
div1.p: Field Notes
Camp Lee

1. Pool, Southside Electric R. R., 1,000′, Petersburg side
of Lakemont Park. Moderate sized pool, breeding anopheles freely,
also culex. This close to camp is made by electric railroad's fill.
Drain or fill.

2. Opposite this, between E. R. R. and N. & W. R. R., is a
pool and marsh large. An ideal A. place; breeding A moderately, C
freely. Also pool across R. R. (In-side) also breeding.

3. Ditch, S. side N. & W. breeding A. So is one on N. Side,
slightly. This is at 2 mile post, N. & W.

Both (2) and (3) can be drained to creek. Both caused by
N. & W. R. R.

4. Two small pools at Lakemont Park, southside of E. R. R.,
A and C.
Drain and fill.

5. North of R. R. beyond a cross road, a large swamp, phy-
sically well suited for A. A in moderate number (and C same) found.
Drain into Skipwith Creek.

6. Ditch S. side N. & W. R. R. opposite this place A freely.
Ditch north side, A moderately.
Drain as (5).

7. Ditch cut to drain N. & W. right of way, running towards
the church at Roseland Park and not far from it. Is full of water
and breeding C. Many Aedes sylvestres in woods adjacent. This ditch
is blocked and the right of way which it should drain (mainly to the
north of the railroad), is breeding A and C freely.

Remove obstructions and grade ditch so as to flow. Drain right
of way.

-2-
8. Down concrete road, one-fourth of a mile and off on road
to southeast, many roadside pools, some permanent. C freely, A mod-
erately. Not of much importance, too far from camp for their size.
Fill if anything is judged needed.

9. Afternoon. Out Middle Road from church across Bailey's
Creek, then road east of south. Well at old saw-mill too deed to
dip (culex?)
Fill with saw-dust, of little importance.

10. Hence, a half mile to Court House Road and half mile east
on Court House Road to first road leading north, and a half mile on
this road is a pond, blocked by a road, 150′ × 25′, breeding A pro-
fusely-- 20 at some dips, all sizes.
Drain across road. This will be easy.

Small branch enters this last pond and runs 800′ to con-
nect almose at right angles with what seems to be the ditch from the
pond (examined on 13th) on Court House Road, northeast of infantry
barracks. This pool is shown on plot given Dr. Hillman, for freeing
within camp.

11. Returned by this same road from Middle to Court House Road,
and 600′ from the latter, on the west side of this road, a pond 100′ ×
15′, breeding A and C both in fair numbers. Pond blocked by road.
Drain at the cross roads, which is easy.
July 16.

Middle section of Harrison's Creek in the woods above Lake-
mont. Good deep banks and free flow. No side swamps up to where
pipe line crosses. 600′ higher up is an under-bluff marsh, small and
very shady, runs almost up to the old dam, not much importance unless
cleared. If cleared, to be drained, Culex moderate numbers.

Above this are a number of side marshes up to the forks of the
creek, all negative and not well suited for A at present, in dense
-3-
growth amd far from blood supply. Doubtless breed C, some of which are
taken. Easy to drain if required. First branch on the right negative.
First branch on the left, negative.

It is to ne noted that the heavy rains of yesterday and last
night flooded everything, washed out the side pools and left them with
so much water that many places suitable for breeding and which, doubt-
less, had been breeding, do not show larvae now.

Norfolk and Western grading camp, near the head of Harrison
Creek (Dark Swamp Run), at spring.

12. Breeding A freely and C profusely in a wide marsh on the
left bank of this run, from the spring down to the road crossing, 600′.
A bad place for breeding but quite far--3/4 of a mile from the camp
grounds and further from the buildings.
A stream comes in from the right at the road crossing, negative.

Drain the marsh and clear the bed of the stream all the way
down.
Branch coming in on the right above the mule stable, negative.

So is the branch coming in from the right below the crossing,
although there is a pool (marl pit) near Mr. Haush's house, full of
C.

Some under-cliff marshes on the left side below the road
crossing-- of small importance, breeding C only at present, and quite
distant from the camp.

Obstructions should be removed from the bed of Harrison Creek
the whole way down. This is a small job and, with a very little
draining of side marshes, would, I believe, be sufficient. It is doubt-
ful if this creek is the source of any considerable number of A.

-4-
Afternoon.
Miss Webb's Spring, Monument, Pa. Regiment.
Just above road crossing, A found--road dam as usual.

13. Valley of stream seems clear of breeding places until about
100′ below the spring. Here, there is a false channel in pools and a
long seepage area, which is permanent, under the bluff. C breeding
profusely in the latter. No A. (In thick brush).

This creek was entered at several (5) places, and its valley
was very dense and rough, but except at this place, no water outside
the creek bed was found. Such may exist however, but it was not possi-
ble with the time at our disposal to explore the creek at all places.
We followed it to its junction with the main creek.

Remove obstructions from the creek bed, which is fairly deep,
and drain any side-pools or under-bluff marsh which may require it.
There are believed to be but few.

This is the right hand fork of Harrison Creek, the other
one having been visited this morning (Dark Swamp Run).

14. About 300′ north of east of Webb Spring is another spring
by two poplars. Below this is a marshy place, breeding A profusely.
Drain.

Blackwater Creek and its branches was visited and crossed
in a number of places from July 13-17. It is in flood and its valley
and that of its affluents, being very flat and the banks shallow, the
streams were all well out of bank--some 200′ to 300′ wide. No exami-
nation was then possible.

There is no reason to change the plan for the canalization
of this stream, agreed on with Mr. Messer before the camp was estab-
lished. It will probably yield a fair number of pestiferous mosqui-
toes and some A unless much pains is taken. It is not believed to
be a bad place for A, but this judgment is
-5-
based on its physical characteristics. No sufficient biological exam-
ination was possible. The valley is densely wooded.

15. There is an area below the signal tower of the N. & W.
R. R., partly caused by its barrow pit, breeding anopheles quite freely,
and which should breed freely later when there is less rain. This area
is on both sides of the track. On the north side extends down to the
bridge over the creek--a branch of Blackwater--and on the south side,
a short distance on both sides of the creek. This is about a half mile
from the camp, further from the barracks. It can be easily drained
into the creek. In spite of the distance, I think this should be done.
July 17.

On Blackwater Creek and branches, all of it within the
reservation.

Creek in flood and close examination impossible. A in swampy
areas in fields near old saw-mill, a half mile southeast of Major Cole's
house--in fair number--woods negative.

This examination was made in wet, the latter part in very wet,
weather. Naturally, then, a number of places breeding in ordinary
weather would have been washed out and found negative in this survey;
also, on account of the flooding of pools, larvae were harder to find
than would have been the case normally. A survey in normal weather,
then, would have shown more breeding places and more breeding in such
places than is here indicated.

Camp Lee
Field notes/17
